questions.question_text: Which three are true about Transparent Data Encryption (TDE)? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ADE
Ref.: https://www.oracle.com/database/technologies/faq-tde.html
C. Wrong: TDE stores its master key in an Oracle Wallet
I think answer ADE. There is always one current master key.

I think ABD?
Can someone give some advice

comments.content: C is wrong. Oracle Database Vault is optional

choices.F: It encrypts only data on the client.
choices.E: It uses a single master key for a database.
choices.D: It can encrypt data at the column level.
choices.A: It stores the current and all past master keys in the keystore.
choices.C: Master encryption keys are managed by Oracle Database Vault.

discussion.content:
I think answer D,E.
Answer C is not a requirement.
Doc. https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMIN/cdb_plug.htm#ADMIN13850

I think CE

Prerequisites

1. You must be connected to a CDB and the current container must be the root.

2. You must have the CREATE PLUGGABLE DATABASE system privilege.

3. The CDB in which the PDB is being created must be in READ WRITE mode.

Managed Files to generate file names. If you are not using Oracle Managed Files, then the database uses the PDB_FILE_NAME_CONVERT initialization parameter to generate file names. If this parameter is not set, then an error occurs.

https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SQLRF/statements_6010.htm#SQLRF55686

comments.content: A C is also my bet here

choices.F: The CDB must use Oracle Managed Files.
choices.E: The CDB, which will contain the PDB, must be in READ WRITE mode.
choices.B: A default service for the new PDB name must already exist.
choices.C: A PDB local administrative user must be granted the DBA role when creating the PDB.
choices.D: A PDB local administrative user must be specified when creating the PDB.
choices.A: The CDB must have PDB_FILE_NAME_CONVERT configured before executing the command.

questions.question_text:
You plan to create a new PDB by copying PDB$SEED.
Which two requirements ensure a successful creation? (Choose two.)

choices.A: The cumulative incremental level 1 database backup ignores the block change tracking file.
choices.E: The block change tracking file will be updated automatically after creation to refer to modified blocks contained in the incremental level 0 database backup.
choices.D: The cumulative incremental level 1 database backup fails.
choices.B: Future cumulative incremental level 1 database backups will reference the block change tracking file.
choices.C: Future incremental level 0 database backups will reference the block change tracking file.

comments.content: That's why A/C is my option
You are wrong. In this case, it still perform level 1 incremental backup, and it will scan all datafiles instead of using change tracking file. I had tested it.

discussion.content: Level 0 backup will be proceed after you enable block change tracking file even you specified an level 1 incremental backup

I think AC
The track file will not be used until the next level 0

questions.question_text: Which two are true about incremental backups? (Choose two.)

comments.content: F is correct because if tracking block is enable level 0 dont backup all blocks

discussion.content:
I think answer A, B, C and F
Answer A because a level 0 incremental backup can be a backupset or imagecopy.
Answer B is because the starting point for an incremental backup strategy is called a level 0 incremental backup...
Answer D is wrong I think because incremental level 1 backups are intended to only backup changed blocks 
Doc: https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/ADMQS/GUID-74D6A06A-EC88-4CF0-B486-7B68DE4A78E4.htm#ADMQS09311
F:wrong level 0 backup only used blocks not unused

Vote for AC
At the beginning of a backup strategy, RMAN creates an image copy backup of the datafile. Then, at regular intervals, such as daily, level 1 incremental backups are taken, and applied to the image copy backup, rolling it forward to the point in time when the level 1 incremental was created.
F- you could backup only used blocks(not all blocks)

comments.content: its A and F. remember, Incremental backup must always be backup as backup sets or compressed backup sets

choices.B: Differential backups can be taken at level 0.
choices.C: An image copy can be used as the baseline for an incremental backup.
choices.F: A database incremental level 0 backup always backs up all database blocks.
choices.A: A backup set can be used as the baseline for an incremental backup.
choices.E: Incremental backups are not permitted when using block change tracking.
choices.D: A tablespace incremental level 1 backup always backs up all blocks in the backed up tablespace.

comments.content: Yes C D. first off, CDB views can be queried even if you are connected to PDB.

choices.D: The data dictionary in CDB$ROOT stores only metadata for objects common to all its PDBs.
choices.B: CDB_views can be queried only from CDB$ROOT.
choices.E: Oracle-supplied data dictionary tables metadata is stored only in CDB$ROOT.
choices.C: Data dictionary metadata for user-created objects is contained in PDB system tablespaces.
choices.A: DBA_views are a superset of CDB_views.
